headline.main: Companies to Pass On More Of Health Costs to Workers

docs.lead_paragraph: Companies next year will push more health care costs onto their workers, who may see an increase of nearly 11 percent in what they have deducted from their paychecks for health insurance, according to a new annual study by Aon Hewitt, a large Chicago benefits consultancy. As companies struggle to control costs in a tough economy, the 2012 annual employee premiums are expected to jump on average 10.6 percent, to $2,306. That figure has doubled since 2005, when workers at larger companies paid on average $1,192 annually per employee and paid about 17 percent of the company's costs, according to Aon Hewitt data.

headline.main: New Survey Projects Higher Employee Health Premiums

docs.abstract: Another survey of major employers shows that workers may shoulder an even larger burden of health care premiums in 2012.

headline.seo: Chris Christie’s Weight and the Oval Office

docs.lead_paragraph: Chris Christie should not face a weigh-in for the presidency.

headline.seo: In North Korea, Kim Jong-un’s Path to Power Grows Firmer
headline.print_headline: Heir’s Path to Power Grows Firmer in North Korea
headline.main: North Korea’s ‘Dear Young General’ Has Made His Mark

docs.lead_paragraph: A year after Kim Jong-un made his public debut as North Korea’s leader-in-waiting, scenes of the party elite bowing to him have become a staple of the country’s propagandist media.
